comments.commentBody:
About 15 or so years ago, after yet another IOC corruption scandal, the frightened
IOC directors made a great display of retaining, at great expense, clean-up consultants. Some cosmetic changes were made, that's it. One of the clever consultants was none other than Henry Kissinger, war criminal and consultant to HRC.
Too right. When a family member of mine gets into the Games, I'll attend. Then, and only then. No reason to support them otherwise.

I love these generalization-heavy, detail-free posts, thundering with criticism and indignation but without one substantiating fact. A shakedown how? Corrupt how? Greedy how? Reform how? This might be the age of sound bites and simplification, but facts still do have relevance and use and power. Let's use them.

Hosting the Olympics is no longer anything more than another shakedown by the IOC, one of the world's most corrupt international organizations.

The winners of the competition sidestep a chance to lose billions and cripple their economies for years to come. The losers get to host the Olympics.

Say NO to IOC greed and corruption. The US should never host another Olympics until the IOC is reformed.
I say let Greece perpetually host the summer games but on a 2 or 3 year interval.
Or, "If you're in a room full of gamblers and you can't figure out who the sucker is, you're the sucker."

[[MJG Boston
Hosting the Olympics is simply a status symbol, like trophy wives. If a US city wants to tear up their city for 12 months in preparation only to take a financial hit, then the powers that be need their heads examined.]]

The point is that certain people make lots and lots of money. People with undervalued land and insider connections do very well. Construction companies, steel and concrete manufacturers, banks, unions.

Politicians are just happy to cut a few ribbons (and, later, accept positions on the boards of the aforementioned companies).

Your idea is great, but the idea of spreading out the Olympics to several cities would not work well. There would be lots of cost overruns (at least here in Quebec), and what would a small city do with facilities after the games. We did have equestrian events out of Montreal, and I assume the white-water rafting, but aside form that everything remained in Montreal (1976).
Except the sailing events, which were held in Kingston, Ontario.  That city is still using the Olympic Harbour very effectively 40 years later.

In reply to Ginnie Kozak:

Great to here that there are some facilities that have lasted this long!

London kept local re-use in mind in its designs, including a major stadium designed to be re-configured for smaller crowds. Designers are brilliant- no problem with building for two 12-year usages. I love the Olympics. Its the best showcase for a host nation you can get, and best to bring all the nations together in one place. However, smaller cities within a country would be overjoyed to host a portion. The one-use  system needs to go away.
Mitt didn't "save" them, one of his minions who didn't seek the limelight, a financial wizard, did.

Not sure what you did. I registered my car using the VIN and was told that I would be receiving $26,000 for a 2013 Turbo Diesel Beetle. It was all pretty clear to me. I was also told that the buyback should begin in November and registered the dealership to which I would be bringing the car.

Sure, and make sure that anyone that ever collected a paycheck at a VW factory or dealership loses their job forever.  And sue anyone who benefited in any way from the emissions cheats, including past and present VW owners who got better mileage and lower fuel costs.

You have no clue what you are talking about if you don't own one.  We are being forced to "fix" our vehicles and the only result to us is that our performance and mileage will not be even close to what was advertised to us when we bought the cars.  Trying to resell a VW of any kind right now is a joke.  Exactly what do you define as "minimal" seeing as you obviously don't own a VW?
I don't know how my response above got posted as it did.  I was not replying to the post above, obviously.  Sorry.

I hardly think it is possible to force VW to pay too much.
They should have to buy back ALL of these cars at the original purchase price, plus pay a hefty penalty. And when they find the engineers who put this together, they should send them to prison.
You bought the cars and smell a windfall.

To make sure that there are exactly 2 Rs and 2 Ds takes a little more work and can only be done with RegEx.

RegEx Mode: 137 results for regular expression
^[^DR]*R[^DR]*R[^DR]*D[^DR]*D[^DR]*$

"I don't know about the rest of you, but VW has only offered $10.1k per car, not $20k."

According to the VWGOW claims web site, after entering the VIN and other info, the buyback amount for my 2011 SportWagen TDI with ~53000 miles on it now is $14k. The additional compensation is ~$6k. Total is $20k.

I don't understand how the buyback value or the additional money were determined. I am going to the library tomorrow to look for a print copy of the Kelly Blue Book from last September so I can look up the resale value. Given that these cars were previously touted for their excellent resale value, $14K after 4 ½ years for a car that was $29k new seems low-ball. I guess they're using the dealer-trade-in number instead of the private-party resale number, or maybe they're just playing a game of take it or leave it. But by offering only $14k for the buyback, they're establishing the ceiling of the resale value, and when the firmware updates that fix the problem come out and drivers see the performance hit, the resale value will go even lower.

I suppose I could sell the car back to VW, wait for them to fix it, then come back and offer $9k for my old car.
And I thought you bought the car for something else than a resale value...

George N. Wells,

Your 2nd paragraph is spot on. There a plenty of racists, but there are few that have the instincts to utter the absurd comments that seem to create the spectacle created by Mr. Trump. My evidence is using the random walk statistical methodology, I only watch CNN at lunch and Mr. Trump was the marquee topic most of the time. This was many months prior to the convention. I think the relationship was mutually beneficial and still is. It is the only explanation for the success of his being non politically correct and disrespectful of politics (Congress can be bought and I know it because I have bought them) patois that captured the TV ratings, media clicks, and print ink.

Trump is a legendary con. It is obvious.

According to most accounts, the supposed "gunshot" was really a woman that maybe thought she kind of heard something that sort of sounded like a gunshot. One report stated that she may have confused the clapping emanating from one of the nearby televisions for a possible gunshot.

There is a difference between vigilance and preparedness, and sheer panicked overreaction. What happened at JFK was quite clearly the latter. We have become a sad, frightened country. Kind of pathetic.

So many medical truisms supported on flimsy evidence seem to harden into fact with enough time and repetition. Death by medical error is a prime example. If one examines the literature the series of papers that tout the mid six figure estimates are extrapolations based on other extrapolation.

It reminds me of the telling of the 10 plagues at Passover where the rabbis argue about how man plagues there really were. At the end the original 10 is now two hundred fifty. While the comparison is not perfect the stakes are also different in medicine versus theology.

How about we publish this, "medical mistakes are really not good things and can kill people. Please adjust your settings accordingly".
Yes indeed and that is why such things happen.

What the heck? why didn't anyone who was in charge come over the intercom and say what was going on, or even not going on? They are lucky nobody was trampled in the crowd. Ridiculous. Do we live in America, or where???
"...so many middle class people filling up the seats..."  Oh, the horror!

Dan. Peace will reign when the population isthinned, say from 6 billion to four. Between wars and climate change, that should do it. This pruning is painful and is an injustice to most of those 2 billion, but the sacrifice is necessary for the greater good.
Or son Welles "Was of the Worlds". This was a sequel, How droll.
Good suggestion. Living in NYC I can see terrorist attack lurking in one's psyche. But for those of us in the periphery it's Wayne LaPierre and the NRA which makes our bones quake. Henry Penny
They are there for appearance of safety. No one believes they would know what to do in an emergency. Am referring to the big airports.
For some reason, this debacle made me think of a Twilight Zone episode, "The Monsters Are Due on Maple Street".

comments.userLocation: Way Out West between Broadway and Philadelphia
comments.commentBody: In investigative journalism of this sort, often a point is reached at which it is necessary to "go with what you have," in the hope that someone who knows something will be overcome with a desire to come forward with it.  Remember how the Watergate story gradually emerged.  And remember that Woodward and Bernstein had to trust "Deep Throat."

Well otherwise:
There is more " evidence" showing pay for play with Mrs. Clinton than there is for these assertions. Are you making the same allowances for that investigative reporting? Oh, that's right, there isn't any reporting on that. We are faced with two candidates with very questionable characters and associations. We should be reading about that.But no, we have evil Donald and saint Hillary. What rubbish.

Comparing Woodward and Bernstein to the journalists bringing us reports from Ukraine's "anti-corruption" agency is surely a bit over the top! As Magpie says below, media is following its biases in what stories it pursues and what it does not. Hillary will stay safe and sound this way, we can see.

The struggling pro-US Ukrainian government's "corruption investigation" targeting the previous president it toppled can be safely expected to deliver what will win favor from the next American president. Mr Manafort's credibility might not be much higher than the anti-corruption investigators', but media should beware giving high profile exposure to this case unless they see evidence, which at the moment investigators themselves say they do not have.
I think it refers to the term "Life Hack" which simply means: a strategy or technique adopted in order to manage one's time and daily activities in a more efficient way.
why not just call it creative problem solving? the word "hack" carries a negative connotation to me

They're both bad.

Clinton and Trump are the best we can do? We are doomed.

Julia, the problem with your Clinton conspiracy is that the uranium deal had to be approved by a committee of representatives "from a number of U.S. government agencies." Clinton was not the representative for State, and State was not the only agency that signed off. Were they all in cahoots to sell out the U.S. for the benefit of Clinton?

I wouldn't be concerned about Manafort either -- except that Putin appears to be leaking emails to help Trump, and Trump's only demand for the GOP platform was to soften language about helping Ukraine defend itself from Russia. He didn't ask for changes on his signature issues like trade and immigration, but only on this obscure Russia-related issue that I would not have guessed he even knew about. It's odd, especially in reference to his antipathy for NATO and fondness for Putin.

You see the problem? If all the nefarious Clintons and associates dropped dead tomorrow, would you be OK with the election connections between Putin and Trump, and the U.S. stance on Russian territorial expansion?

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/24/us/cash-flowed-to-clinton-foundation-a...

PS. You might need to replace your keyboard if the Shift key keeps getting stuck like that.
